subject: AI
title: Recursive Chunking
description: A chunking strategy that respects document structure by splitting at natural boundaries.

hook.text: You split a document every 500 tokens. A paragraph about 'machine learning applications' gets cut in half â€” one chunk says 'applications include' and the other says 'healthcare and finance.' Neither chunk is useful alone.

buildup.text: Recursive chunking tries to split at natural boundaries: first by section headers, then paragraphs, then sentences, then words â€” only going deeper when a chunk exceeds the target size.

discovery.text:
The algorithm: try splitting on '

' (paragraphs). If any chunk is still too large, split those on '
' (lines). Still too large? Split on '. ' (sentences). This preserves semantic coherence.

twist.text: Recursive chunking is the default strategy in LangChain for a reason â€” it balances chunk size consistency with semantic coherence better than fixed-size splitting for most document types.

climax.text: Combine recursive chunking with metadata (source document, section header, position) for chunks that are both well-sized and well-labelled.

punchline.text: Split where the text naturally breathes. Paragraphs are better boundaries than byte counts.

quiz.question: How does recursive chunking differ from fixed-size chunking?
